I concur. There are time bombs in contracts that require completion by specific dates, and the onus is on the buyers and the buyers' team to meet deadlines.

A 72 hour review period would be well-advised although it will cause delays and added time pressure on the current process - especially when competing against all cash offers.

I provided pro bono counseling to many distressed homeowners. Invariably I'd hear stories and see the evidence that terrible loan conditions were imposed due to last minute submittal of loan agreements for buyer review. Pre-payment penalties when none should have been imposed, higher settlement fees, excessive fees to mortgage brokers, falsified income in the mortgage broker's handwriting, double and triple dealing by a mortgage broker who was also representing the seller AND the buyer, with a 3% bonus commission for a sub-prime loan plus 6% gross commission on the sale and the appraisal had been "juiced" well above market. And that was only what I could see 5 years after the fact. It was impossible to know whether the property was as advertised, inspections had been properly rendered or permits for updates had ever been issued.

On the investment properties of 1-4 units with which I have been involved, nearly always the loan docs and closing package arrive as we're sitting at the escrow office ready to sign. The commercial deals are different but those have higher net worth parties who can afford to hold out for removal of unsatisfactory terms.

"Last minute changes in terms are would not be tolerated by neither institutional buyers and sellers, nor institutional borrowers and lenders."

That's bull and parties to a contract should have the freedom to change that contract prior to it being signed. But of course liberals want to protect us all from our bad decisions. The last minute angle is frankly not true either. If you're presented with confusing terms at the last minute then DON'T SIGN the contract. Tell them you need time to review it and won't sign if any more changes are made. If some people are either not smart or careful enough to manage their affairs, that is their problem. The government can't protect everyone from their bad decisions.

Of the flaws cited, the most significant is permitting lenders to revise loan terms with no or little advance warning to consumers.  Most consumers, including fairly sophisticated residential borrowers, do not have the wherewithal to evaluate and act on such changes meaningfully.  Last minute changes in terms are would not be tolerated by neither institutional buyers and sellers, nor institutional borrowers and lenders.  The same standards would ideally govern consumer transactions.

First, all meats are high in tryptophan (relatively speaking), so if you ate a good sized meal of fish, meat, or poultry (chicken actually has slightly more tryptophan than turkey), you should get the same results if it was just the tryptophan.

In fact, administering pure tryptophan alone does contribute to sleepiness. Tryptophan is metabolized in the cerebrospinal fluid to give serotonin, and then melatonin, both of which may have significant affect on sleepiness.

But this will not happen from eating turkey. Turkey is also rich in other amino acids that compete with tryptophan for transport into the brain, and these amino acids (branched chain amino acids) are more common than tryptophan is. As a result, tryptophan is transported relatively slowly across the blood brain barrier- too slowly to build up the required serotonin and melatonin concentrations to have much effect.

However, if you eat lots of carbs with your meal, this triggers insulin release, which causes muscles to preferentially absorb branched chain amino acids. This permits more rapid uptake of tryptophan and a greater synthesis of serotonin and melatonin.

So to review. It's not the turkey. It's really the carbs. Anytime you change the ratio of BCAA's to tryptophan, you can induce greater tryptophan uptake and therefore synthesis of melatonin. Eating carbs is one way to do this. Eating pure tryptophan is another.

You commented: "But I disagree that hard work is inevitably its own reward."
Exactly which part of these two excerpts from Mr. Blow's excellent column did you NOT understand?
1. "I fully understand that trying hard doesn’t always guarantee success. Success is often a fluky thing, dependent as much on luck and favor as on hard work. But while hard work may not guarantee success, not working hard almost always guarantees failure." - He totally says hard work is no guarantee of success. I infer he means financial and socio-economic success.
2. "Trying hard and working hard is its own reward. It feeds the soul. It affirms your will and your power." Here I understand that, in the simplest sense, he's saying that striving generates self-respect, which can lead to perseverance and, at least, some progress up the metaphorical hill.

I think work is often inherently dignifying and satisfying, aside from how it may advance your position. This breaks down, I realize, when one is working for next to nothing or doing work that is dangerous or demeaning in some way. And, no doubt about it, we need to change the way work is rewarded so that people who work make a living wage instead of a misery wage.

But if you are looking for your own locus of control, then work is one thing that can be rewarding and strengthening: many kinds of work bring a sense of satisfaction. This is even more important for students to realize: real study brings knowledge and often insight, and a sense of mastery.

The social world rotates around gathering low hanging fruit. For the poor this is unhelpful and inaccurate. It is astronomically more important for every oppressed person to first be strong. No one will tell you that.

The poor lack credibility. That means they cannot call the police, talk to the teacher, and must conceal the continual wounds of vulnerability. It isn't the herculean force that wins for most, but the rigid daily mantra of persistence. Every strength must be tuned and ready for performance. This effort must be preformed with little guidance and zero reward.

I guess it also means that what survivors hate most is people who lie or lazy people who portray some social manipulation as salvation. The work is about being eternal and vigilant. Maybe it will never win, but truth will be your companion. While it doesn't make life easy, it is a gem of credibility.

I agree in part and disagree in part with this essay. I agree that (very) hard work is typically necessary to advance upward along life's hill, especially if one has started from the bottom. And I know that resilience and faith are required to cope with the setbacks often encountered along the way.

But I disagree that hard work is inevitably its own reward. Hard work frequently results in failure. In some instances, hard work is greeted with barriers imposed by others seeking to displace a competitor's advance, especially if the competitor is from a group that has not traditionally been expected to advance.

It is indeed a bitter pill when hard work results in failure or additional discrimination or new setbacks. Those who have encountered disappointing results or additional obstacles need to be grounded in the faith that additional work will lead to a tangible reward, whether financial, reputational or in the learning attained on life's journey.

Accept my apologies -- to your wife. I conflated her quite reasonable drink with your comment about shaken Belvedere. The only reason to shake a drink is to make it frothy, which no decent vodka deserves. Either keep it in the freezer or stir, gently, with ice.

We celebrate New Year's three times, on 1/1, the Sunday after Superbowl (for ikebana people) and 1/13, with our Russian friends who celebrate it by the "old calendar" (Julian because that Pope Gregory guy was not to be trusted). We drink lots of vodka, all the cheapest available, frozen until it's oily. Most of it has all manner of weeds steeping in the jugs. They laugh at your fancy vodkas and would do unspeakable acts to anyone caught shaking it with ice.

You've never partied until you've partied with Russians. The Cupertino police are used to my friends' annual gathering. If they find someone singing in a large fountain, they know just where to drop him off.

Reality check: voting is, like remarriage, the triumph of hope over experience. Until every office has a one-term limit, the most important thing for winners of elections is to do whatever is necessary to win the next election.

@Nat Erlich

It’s the funding, not the terms that is the problem. A good Senator (such as Herb Kohl, who served my state for many years) should not be booted if voters want him or her. Term limits would likely result only in a series of puppets propped up by the Party. It is the incessant fund-raising that is the problem.

If I have a blanket criticism of those who start at the bottom of the hill and never get very far up it (often due to circumstances beyond their control), it  is that they don't vote in large enough numbers. You outnumber those at the top, and your votes can make a difference.  It was heroic that minorities stood in line for hours to vote last year, but will they do the same in 2014?  Or will it be 2010 all over again?  Republicans are making it difficult for you to vote, so you will have to go that extra mile to make a difference.  Many of those at the top of the hill or those who have climbed upward think all those below are inferior moochers and takers.  We must not let those who lack all empathy and kindness win elections by default.

"Breakdown of the family"

From the ideologues of the right (including your Times colleagues Brooks and Douthat), that's the go-to explanation for poverty - never the slightest understanding that poverty can be so oppressive that it can destroy families and, increasingly these days, prey on young people so much as to inhibit them from starting families.

The truth is that if you have a hill to climb, your determination to climb it is opposed by more than mere gravity, which can always be overcome. Today's prevailing economic forces can kick you right back down. Their existence is no accident; they are the inevitable result of policies that favor the already favored.

Mr. Blow, this was an admirable piece of writing. I would have added just one more piece of advice. If you are at the bottom and you want to climb, one of the ways up is to get out and vote, get your friends to vote. There are more of you than there are of those who would keep you down. And don't just vote once every four years. Vote every time you have the chance. Above all, vote whatever obstacles are put in your way.

Going from B to B', you show a constant rate in interest, but that's not what Williamson is proposing so it seems. What Williamson seems to proposing is to raise the liquidity premium by raising the Interest on Reserves. That will reduce the liquidity premium on bonds and since he presents inflation as inversely proportional to bond prices, inflation rises.

Assuming that's his rationale, I also think he is off. In the comment section he writes that the Fed Funds market is all but going through the GSE's. This observation should prompt him to conclude that IOER is too high, not too low. You thought that lowering IOER will do nothing using Japan as an example. However, the GSE's are not an equal opportunity provider of Fed Funds which means that excess reserves are not efficiently being allocated where loan demand is. Basically, most banks are condemned to the side-lines because excess reserves are ring-fenced within only those banks at which primary dealers keep their accounts into which the Fed deposits funds in the process of QE.

So what led Williamson astray? What led him astray is what Brad Delong already explained and you expanded upon: The problem is that there is no rationale for a dynamic mechanism to restore equilibrium, because the Fed has disabled the Fed Funds market and handed a reserve monopoly to the GSE's.

Running against "big government" generally and the ACA specifically the Republicans are trying to hold their electorate together and gain advantage from the tired mantra "government is the problem". Yet this fight is less ideological and more about power and money. Despite trying to base their arguments on notions of small government and to appear grass-roots, the Tea party is controlled by the real masters of the Republican party, the 1% who don't really care about ideology so long as they can make and keep their money. So how does it help the rich and powerful, the "job creators" in Republican parlance, to keep one of six Americans without any or adequate health insurance? I have thought about this, and the answer is elusive, but I'll posit this hypothesis.

Those without insurance live in fear of getting sick, in fear of losing whatever job they have, in fear of complaining about low wages, poor working conditions, or an onerous schedule. They will not fight back by joining a lawsuit or union organizing drive. Rather they learn to accept a bad situation; they adapt to a harsh life; they realize that they won't have what others do; they learn to resent and even hate. This viscious cycle is part of a cynical plan to maintain a permanent under-class. It is the history of the American South where the Tea party and opposition to the ACA are strongest This is also a loss of freedom, but won't be discussed on FOX when those emotions can be exploited for political advantage.

Maybe you missed it, but the "loudmouths" are ordinary Americans who had some sincere, albeit guarded, faith in the ACA and its rollout, only to be told (a) the enrollment process doesn't work, and (b) provisions after provision is being deferred until after the 2014 elections (as there is obviously more chaos to come once these provisions are implemented).   So, maybe you hate the GOP, but they are not the issue.  The issue is that trusting Americans have been sorely misused by Obama and his party.
